conclusion: Two particles A and B start at the same point, move in the same direction along a straight line, start moving simultaneously from rest, and their velocity-time graph is given.
For particle A: accelerates from 0 to v₀ at time t₀, maintains velocity v₀ until time 2t₀, decelerates linearly to velocity 0 at time 3t₀, and remains at rest after 3t₀.
For particle B: accelerates from 0 to v₀ at time 4t₀, maintains velocity v₀ until time 5t₀, and decelerates linearly to velocity 0 at time 6t₀.
For the particles to meet, they must be at the same position at the same time, which means they must have traveled the same distance after starting.
The distance traveled by a particle is the area under its velocity-time graph.
The total distance traveled by particle A is the area under its velocity-time graph, which forms a trapezoid from 0 to 3t₀: Area = (1/2)·(3t₀)·v₀ = 1.5·t₀·v₀.
For particle B, the distance traveled for 0 ≤ t ≤ 4t₀ is the area of a triangle with width t and height (v₀·t)/(4t₀): Distance = (1/2)·t·(v₀·t)/(4t₀) = (v₀·t²)/(8t₀).
For particle B, the distance traveled for 4t₀ ≤ t ≤ 5t₀ is the sum of the distance at 4t₀ (2t₀v₀) and the additional distance v₀·(t-4t₀): Total distance = 2t₀v₀ + v₀·(t-4t₀) = v₀·(t-2t₀).

For particle B, the distance traveled for 5t₀ ≤ t ≤ 6t₀ is the sum of the distance at 5t₀ (3t₀v₀) and the additional distance from the area of the final triangle: Total distance = 3t₀v₀ + (1/2)·(6t₀-t)·v₀ = v₀·(3t₀ + (6t₀-t)/2).
To find when the particles meet, set the distance traveled by B equal to the total distance traveled by A (1.5·t₀·v₀).
For t < 4t₀, the distance traveled by B is (v₀·t²)/(8t₀). Setting this equal to 1.5·t₀·v₀ gives t² = 12t₀², so t = 2√3·t₀ ≈ 3.46t₀.
Since 3.46t₀ < 4t₀, the particles meet during this period.
